poem:
The Herdwick's Gathering

Clink!  
metal whispers,  
herding hands call  
the valley's sheep—  
dense wool,  
and weathered eyes  
meet in Eskdale's heart.  

September folds  
into stories,  
old as Herdwicks,  
stitching time  
with rhythmic feet  
and the land's   
ancient grace.  

Home,  
where laughter  
grazes fields  
and autumn's breath  
is sweet.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: Where the Herdwicks are the star of the show | Andrea Meanwell The familiar clink of the metal hurdles as they open and close tells me I’m “home”: at a shepherds’ meet. Since 1866, on the last Saturday in September, the shepherds of the Lake District have met in Eskdale to celebrate local livestock, crafts and produce. That may sound old, but it started as an additional show to the May Tup Fair,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Country diary: Where the Herdwicks are the star of the show | Andrea Meanwell The familiar clink of the metal hurdles as they open and close tells me I’m “home”: at a shepherds’ meet. Since 1866, on the last Saturday in September, the shepherds of the Lake District have met in Eskdale to celebrate local livestock, crafts and produce.
